Different types of cavalry
>charging heavily armored lancers

>horsearchers

>light cavalry (less armor , lighter weapons, such as normal spears ) to chase a fleeing enemy/ keep the flanks distracted

>cavalry with curved swords during napoleonic warfare, sabers were more effective as cavalry melle weapons because curved blades cut better then flat ones , and had less of a chance to chop into an opponet and get stuck in him while you ride away because you couldnt hold on to it. and infantry had virtually no armor (exceptions for officers and weird units ofc) at the time, so cutting weapons were very effective

As far as other cultures, during medieval warfare, i do not know , many sword designs at that time which did things differently, like african blades made to strike over shields. Curves Probably made the blade harder to bind and to intercept with your own weapon or shield
, during certain stabs.

Tldr Different fightingstyles

Is it worth it to soup up a 10/22 and turn it into a precision rifle? I really like these rifles but I don’t love the configuration I have for mine currently. The takedown will never be a precision gun but I have a stainless non-takedown one I was thinking of turning into a bull barrel, chassis-having bench gun with a big ol optic.

The problem is … the nicer parts (Kidd, Volquartsen) are veryyy expensive. It’s like 1k to build a rifle from reputable brands. There are of course many other companies (ER Shaw, Green Mountain, Faxon) but their reputations for barrels or whatever is mixed or there isn’t much information.

Also finding no info about the benefits of upgrading the bolt to a Kidd or Brownells or something other than the factory one. Same with stocks. Is MagPul ok or should I get one that had bedding? Diamondback tactical FFP or SWFA 10x? Ar mount or rings?

Do any of you 22 guys have some advice? Or some favorite parts and optics that aren’t going to break my wallet in half?

Ideally would like to keep the rifle under $750

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I don't think so. By all means do it if you have the cash to burn, but I don't think the result would be worth the squeeze.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56504730
Just buy the Competition model from Ruger and you don't have to do anything. Fluted and threaded barrel, extended mag release, extra mounting lug on the rear of the receiver, full pic rail, and bolt hold open (doesn't lock open on empty but it makes cleaning the gun much easier) They go for like $750 on gunbroker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56504730
ModShot chassis with a Volquartsen ultralight action. This is around $1k, but if you go with a cheaper action you can probably get it under 750, chassis is like 500, then upgrade action/barrel components down the line

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just keep the 10/22 as is and keep it for non-precision shooting. Spend your money on a 22lr bolt gun from a reputable company and decent ammo. If you insist on a non-locking action, get the Ruger >>56504998 posted.

Personally I'd rather spend the $750 on a basic, centerfire bolt gun with good aftermarket support and some basic reloading equipment if the point is small group sizes. Assuming the rifle was properly made, loading ammo specifically for it is going to make a bigger difference than some fancy new parts. However, you still have the option to kit the rifle out.

posts.name: Burt
posts.com:
>>56504730
I have no experience with high end 10/22s but I did slowly evolve this one over the years and I never saw a greater impact on accuracy than just a Volquartsen (THM) barrel. Pic related is an old pic but you can see it's just a cheapo Hogue stock, factory trigger with an overtravel screw I installed and a rando hunting scope. It probably had a VQ hammer in it at this point and the groups were shot suppressed but just the barrel made this beater 10/22 very much sub-MOA. I think this is just CCI SV though it's been so long it could have been Wolf match ammo that I used to have.

Not saying this is a typical result or to expect it, but the barrel made a massive difference, and they aren't that expensive alone. THM barrels are also very light if that's something you want

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56510364
IR sensors. Though, that depends on if your sensor is Long-Wave Infrared (LWIR), Medium/Mid-Wave Infrared (MWIR), or a dual sensor of both. IIRC the F/A-18E/F IRST21 can target at about the same distance as its radar ~70mi. That's for non-stealth platforms not designed with IR reduction only second to radar reduction like the F-117, B-2, B-21, and F-35A/B/C are. Then you're limited by atmospheric conditions, too. Which will degrade your sensor's ability to see further. The biggest hurdle is the manufacturing, and fielding of IR sensors with the resolution and sensitivity to see very faint IR signatures at long distanced, added to a powerful enough processor to take advantage of your extensive threat library to detect, track, and ID a platform at any angle. The threat library is made up of IR signatures of a known platform at different distances, angles, and configurations. Which takes an extensive ISR system to get in the first place. Other countries would be hard-pressed to make the sensors, let alone have the processing power, algorithms, and threat library to detect US stealth planes at any tactically relevant distances. No, I don't think China can, and Russia definitely can't.

>>56502686
I have seen this, and repeated it myself many times. I think this is not necessarily true. We assign this based on our own perceptions of technological advancement. We progressed from the dawn of civilization to a space-faring race in ~6,000 years, with 5,850 of those being at a technological level a world apart from the latter. It's understandable to come to that conclusion. However, I think what most fail to consider as it is quite morbid, is the very real possibility that it is quite possible to stagnate in technological capability as we are now, or at least at a comparative level from the years preceding the development of electricity, the internal combustion engine, etc.

I have no doubt in the next 100 years we will see some groundbreaking research completed, but progression on a level similar to that from 1922 to today? That cannot be assumed as a surety, or even likely.

Previous >>56355642
nobody made a new thread edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

They don't. PVS-7s use MX10130 format tubes while PVS-14s (And almost everything else these days) use MX11769 or MX10160 tubes. (With 11769 and 10160 tubes being essentially interchangeable and differing only in that the 11769 has a "pigtail" ribbon cable for manual gain control.)

With thermal always start by deciding what optical magnification you want. Then get the highest resolution sensor you can afford with that optical mag.

If your friend wants 1x hand held on a budget one of the best deals is the "GOYOJO Thermal Monocular - Night Vision Imaging 384x288" on Amazon. It's a 1x mag 384 core for $550.

>>56452876
NTA. While no product is perfect for 100% of everyone, the 4D setup is significantly thicker than factory padding and can put you in a spot where a size up on a helmet would have been more appropriate for you with its use. The goal should be to have uniform pressure everywhere the padding touches not just a softer foam in places you are getting hot spots.
IMO start setup from scratch again and dont be afraid to mix and match the 4D with your factory stuff to get that even fit. As long as you get a balanced pressure with the brim ~0.5-0.75" above your brow and side rails parallel to the ground, a G24 should work for the vast majority of people unless its with something like an RNVG without the dovetail extension.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56454859
>>56455017
>>56455552
I have a GP tube with no manual gain so it's always at max gain/brightness. I actually need the purple filter to make the tube comfortable to use, otherwise it can be painfully bright and eye fatigue is a problem. Any time I've compared filter/no filter I've always been able to see just as much with the filter, even in the darkest conditions. It actually seems to help in dark conditions by reducing apparent scintillation and increasing contrast. A big part of this is because sans filter my pupil is just dialing down more in response to the bright screen.

If you have manual gain and are always running at max because of the filter, you are technically reducing the life of your tube. So it's true that there is no free lunch. Still, for an anon on a budget, GP + filter works pretty damn well.

if you're a person that only shoots on an official gun range, dont buy night vision. night vision is best if you have property or large swathes of public land to larp on. Here's how a typical evening goes for me
>locate public land via map app. drive up
>glass all the nearby hills with thermals to make sure we're alone
>set up targets, typically 100 yards
>shoot a bit, warm our guns up check optics and zeroes
>then, we lock the cars and move out
>we practice walking, bounding, and running under NVGs using only IR
>practice designating targets with lasers and radios while separated
>do some map reading and landnav with closefocus apertures
>get tired, go back to cars
>set up campfire, eat dinner, maybe sip some whiskey and smoke
>go home
it's a good time

You'll notice it with 18650 protected batteries having a thin flat wire that goes along the body of the battery to connect the + and - terminal where there's a circuit to add some protections when the battery charges or discharges or when the battery has a built in usb charge port like the surefire or streamlight 18650. From what I can tell most vape devices uses unprotected 18650 so there's a good chance a vape store will only sell unprotected 18650s but I don't vape so I don't know for sure that's the case just only what I've been reading about where you find unprotected 18650.
Regarding the Jerry-C, if the battery is all charged or brand new (cr123) and you hear that distinct click from the off position to the on position, it should display the "initialization" text ASAP on your NVD. This picture is my Jerry-CE5 in the off position, from this orientation you turn it clockwise until you hear the click. I did have to unscrew the plastic knob to get access to the actual dial to tighten down a nut because it got lost over time but that didn't affect turning on or off the Jerry-C just that the button press wouldn't change thermal mode.
You may have to contact Kosher/Custom to RMA it if it's not turning on.

posts.com:
just discovered captive piston ammo from those russian silent mortars, this tech is ingenius.
why is it only used in large caliber shit?
why can't we have captive piston 5.56 ammo going 2700fps?

think about it:
all the gas is contained in the case/projectile, so you don't need a long barrel for expanding gas.
fuck, you could have a long action magnum reaching 3000 fps from a 3 inch barrel or something, just long enough for the rifling to stabilize it.

and if the captive piston was in the bullet, you wouldn't need a case at all!
in fact if we went that far, you could put stabilizing fins on the back of the bullet like mortar rounds have, and nix the rifling entirely. no need to worry about it fitting in a case.
let's not forget the movie quiet operation of this entire system.
and i'm sure a captive piston requires less powder since the space the expanding gas fills is only the size of the chamber vs the entire barrel for normal ammo.

https://youtu.be/vJDA3DuHqJg
here's some 40mm caseless captive piston ammo. this is the future of firearms right here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56510401
You are fundamentally miss understanding how firearms work. Gunpowder burns slowly and generates lots of gas pressure within the chamber. This gas pressure is the fundamental to operating the action regardless of what action is being used.

Your half baked idea attempts to contain this pressure in an even smaller area which would require even higher pressures since you have less time to allow energy to build. You also don’t have a constant pressure as you do with real firearms. The entire time the bullet is in the barrel it is under pressure and gaining energy. Yours is almost instantaneous which would require all the power of a bullet in a fraction of the time actually guns are under pressure. Your idea would turn any gun ever made or concocted into a pipe bomb.
It seems you think it would be a case-less design as well, but you fail to understand newtons 2nd and 3rd laws. The energy used to force the piston back must also be overcome again to drag the piston out with it. This will always prevent you from having an efficient cartridge.
Your “gun” would need to hold 100x the pressure for longer than any current metallurgy can contain. Or you need a 100lb gun to shoot the equivalent of a 9mm with your idea.

What your describing is what modern ammunition already is basically just being super autistic about it.

You (sorta) understand that a bullet is already like a piston. The bullet is pushed through by the propellant and the case (along with many other roles such as obturation) drives the action back (in recoil based designs, not gas operations). You need to loose mass (such as the loss of powder and case) to have any level of efficiency with a cased cartridge.
If your idea includes having the piston be left behind or ejected congrats you’ve just made the worst gun and bullet that could ever be technically be considered a gun and bullet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56509546
any pressure requirement is totally speculative.
letting youtubers live in your head rent free is not a good look.

the force transfer in a captive piston only has to occur for a fraction of the time that a traditional cartridge does.
it also has a fraction of the space that must be filled with that pressure.
a captured piston can use an incredibly short barrel.
many spigot mortars have no barrel at all, as a matter of fact. the fins stabilize it.

a regular cartridge must apply pressure for the entire length of the barrel, and overcome rifling.
they also get the barrel hot, and must eject cases.

weight and durability concerns are baseless.
there is nothing intrinsically weaker or heavier about it.
you're inventing problems to complain about.

take the PSS pistol, for instance. it has a 153 grain .30 cal bullet traveling at 600fps. i am suggesting a sub 100 grain spitzer bullet, preferably .50 cal for increased powder volume and a high BC.
keep in mind the SP4 captive piston ammo is a retrofitted 7.62x39 case using a solid bullet with a very tiny powder charge. picrel
i am suggesting a hollow bullet with a much more voluminous charge.
it is absolutely feasible. perhaps the hypothetical bullet will end up being as light as 50 grains.
it's simply a shell containing powder and a flat piston similar in size to the SP4's.

The only way you're getting 100 grains is if you take the piston along with you. The extra weight in the back will make the bullet tumble in the air, ruining any chance of accuracy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let's talk about poor fag comms again. Before you run off and buy a HAM radio you should consider GMRS.
HAM radio is cool and all but chances are communicating with your family and friends in your local area will be the top priority over making contact with strangers miles and miles away.
GMRS radios use preset channels making it easy for your boomer parents to use.
One GMRS lioscense is good your entire immediate family.
The baofang UV-5G/UV-5X (they're the same thing but the 5X software is updated) has the exact same look and takes the same accessories as the UV-5R (because looking cool is everything)
There's probably a GMRS repeater or two near you that will extend your range.
GMRS can communicate with shitty FRS walkie talkies if that's all your friends/family have. Buy two GMRS radios.
They can also receive NOAA weather reports and alerts as well as commercial FM radio.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56482114
All of this shit should fit in the 4 type 56 grenade pouches.
Oil bottle (in the wax lined outer pouch where it belongs)
Baofeng or other small radio (you might need to add a paracord loop extension to close the flap)
Gloves combat gauze, compressed gauze, TK4 tourniquet, credit card wrapped in ducttape inside sandwich bag
One israeli bandage or other compression dressings take up a whole pouch by themselves so make an additional IFAK to store those and some real cheat seals. The above one pouch IFAK is obviously not enough.
Leatherman, chapstick, spare batteries, mini bic lighter, mini pencil/sharpie.

Really good list. I usually keep most things stored this way in a Ziploc. Baofengs with extended batteries have trouble fitting, but I'd bring a spare battery anyways. I tuck a bolt scraper/cleaning tool in with the lube (plus another pair of nitrile gloves for cleaning, first pair goes in the medical pouch). Also don't underestimate how small and useful a wire saw is. Also consider tucking supplies in the bottoms of the mag pouches
>bb roll of duct tape
>ace bandage
>mosquito headnet
>roll of 550 cord
Ideally things that you don't need immediate access too. But if you can shift cleaning kit to a mag pouch it frees up your easily accessible pouches for first aid and other critical supplies

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56502860
>>56503594
Take it apart. Particularly under the forend check the status of the piston, op rod running back to the receiver, return spring (probably wrapped around the outside of the magazine tube) and any gas rings. I remember TFB had a Turkish shotgun with a similar design where overpowered shells would pop a rubber gasket on the piston loose and it would bind things up. Hopefully it's just that.

If you get in it and nothing looks bent or pushed out of where it's supposed to be, try just cleaning it. If it's still not working, contact the importer. Might need to go back for warranty work.
>>56501031
Yes, they are featureless rifles and the magazine is non removable.
Due to a separate provision in the AWB adding a detachable magazine is illegal even if it remains featureless, but that's a stupid thing to do anyway.
>>56501211
Ruger PC is a good option too.
KT SU-16 A, B and CA are legal as well, but shitty.
It's possible to find stupid good deals on used Mini-14s if you get lucky, but it relies on luck. Everyone wants $1000-1200+ for them nowadays in which case you're better off saving a few more bucks towards an M1A.

It's a Slappers Only saying. I guess that you don't need to do that stupid H&K-slap dance like with a G3, but pulling the trigger as needed until it does nothing, then swapping mags and racking the action in one simple motion, isn't exactly unique to the Kalashnikov, no.

The actual strength of the AK is that it's very robust, and maintenance is as simple as unloading, taking off the top cover, and then taking out the BCG and spring, and then you can easily access the internals. The other advantage is that it's cost effective. Some people think stamping is automatically cheap, and it's not, but others think that fact means there's no cost advantage at all to stamping, which is also wrong, it's cost effective when you know you're making shitloads upon shitloads of guns, so when the machines and dies are made and paid off for 50+ years ago, that means it actually IS a lot cheaper to make a stamped AKM receiver than forging and machining one. That said, you still gotta forge and machine your trunnions and BCGs, so it'll still cost some money, and if you don't do it right, the gun is gonna be shit.

It's appealing to poorfag conscription armies in that way, because it's tough for even the most retarded and negligent conscript to fuck the gun up so hard that it needs to go to the armory, and if it does, it's not too tough to fix.

>>56510428
Having used both military 7.62x39 AK and civilian 5.56x45 AR-pattern rifles I think that AK pattern rifles would be harder to understand for a complete noguns/child and they are also far less comfortable to shoot. The fire selector is somewhat illogical, its markings are bad and it's easy to flip into wrong position accidentally under stress.
Meanwhile AR15 are lighter - better for kids - usually have better adjustable stocks - better for kids - have better markings on switches - better for kids - have way less felt recoil and the recoil is better directed for less muzzle climb - better for kids.

The main "simplicity" advantage an AK has is its reciprocating charging handle. Even a monkey could intuit what's going on in the machine after experiencing it in motion. This would make solving malfunctions easier without foreknowledge of how to identify and deal with them. Simply finding the charging handle in AR could take a while and clearing jams is arcane when the parts aren't clearly connected and you don't have full control of the bolt movement.

Hard to say about maintenance. Field stripping is not something you can intuit just by getting handed either type of rifle. It would take a bit of experimenting in both cases to figure it out without instructions. But I think AK is simpler there.

>>56514369
>The very procedure is rarely needed due to the long stroke gas piston keeping the fouling away from the bolt, unlike the M16 which uses the fucking bolt as the piston.
You don't really need to clean the BCG much on an AR15.

>>56514527
>7 puny lugs
Seven lugs add up, as does the pressure put towards the bolt which alleviates pressure from the discharging cartridge (hence why HK416 bolts break faster). It doesn't need to be overgassed to function reliably.

>giant hole through bolt for cam which shouldn't be a separate part in the first place
>only thing keeping the bolt from closing early is the cam pin grinding on the upper
Considering there's no peening going on, there's clearly no grinding and it's mechanically fine.

>gajillion tiny parts in the BCG
You don't need to detail strip the BCG for cleaning. You talk as if you need to take off the gas rings or the gas key.

>buffer tube
It contributes to the precision and lack of recoil.

>fucking buffer tube retainer snapping
That either means your buffer, tube, or carrier isn't in spec, or that you've been racking the action when the barrel isn't installed. Solutions include adjusting or replacing one of the parts in question, and not racking the bolt on a rifle which isn't assembled.
Optionally, just omit the detent entirely if you're paranoid about it, the gun will function without it, it'll just make disassembly and reassembly more awkward.

>johnson LMG but with DI niggerrigged into it
>button based controls
>shit mag locking system
>forward assist + the worst charging handle design ever

lmao

Wouldn't call developing an all new gas system to be niggerrigging, that would be like putting a MAS59 style gas tube onto it and then plain having it push on a cup on the bolt carrier, which isn't what the AR15 is doing. Mag stays in fine, only other button you'll find yourself using is the bolt release, which is more like paddle, and you'll bump it after seating a mag. Selector can be used with your thumb.

>>56514825
It's intuitive as a safety but not so much as a fire selector.
The positions of full and semi auto should have been reversed so they are in order from No Bang -> Some Bang -> Most Bang like any sensible control ever, be it a valve, a car pedal, a volume knob, a fire selector, or anything.

It's a really perplexing design choice. It's even a real world drawback. Most combat situations where a soldier would want to switch to full auto are going to be hasty and full of adrenaline. When you have a huge lever that's operated with your whole arm, it gets slammed down from safe or accidentally all the way back to safe from semi. A thumb control that is always operated with the same degree of finesse wouldn't be so bad if the controls were in wrong order. On the AK selector it is a fatal flaw.

Further the US does not stand alone, it is part of the "free world". Since the spat with King George III the US has always considered itself anti-imperialist and since Woodrow Wilson it has been set upon the doctrine of winning over other countries and integrating them into global trade. The US earned its position due to its doctrinal stance as much as the size of its economy, China may gain the latter but never the former unless it makes major political reforms that would result in the communist party losing power.

This is why China can't help but antagonize its neighbors, why it embarked on its meme island building project in the South China sea and why it struggles even to subvert tiny nations like Palau, it has to separate itself from the free world and can only rely on street hood intimidation and bribery. Sure, African countries and whoever takes their money and exports the bauxite to them, but they will never really be loyal, they won't stick with them through thick and thin, there are always western bidders waiting in the wing, although they won't bribe as much. Its only significant allies are Pakistan and Russia and only out of convenience due to their spats with other nations.

One day China's GDP will exceed the US's, and there will be mass hysteria, but as the years roll by people will realize it is meaningless.

I use Shipstation through Paypal to weigh, buy and ship presents from home. Even after pp discounts, USPS still charges MORE for everything than UPS, with twice the calculated delivery time.

The only thing USPS had going was cost effectiveness and convenience. The corner post dropbox even installed a letter slit so you can't use it for 1st class packages anymore.

Lesson learned, UPS gang for life. Free tracking and delivery confirmation.
If you can, I'd suggest switching over next year to see a lot less presents misdirected and "lost" by grubby little monkey fingers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56504275
>I miss classic big-budget OAVs
I share the exact same sentiment. With one of, if not, the greatest of all, LOGH as my favorite. With OVAS, the show’s production teams have more freedom to write and animate the story has they please, aren’t hampered by televising companies or broadcast laws, can go below or beyond the typical 24 minute TV episode block, can make as many (or little episodes as possible, and font have to meet TV deadlines.
Patlabor is a great example of this. The original OVA and the sequel OVA for the TV series does a great job of encapsulating Patlabor. They feature content and scenes that wouldn’t have been on the televised series and the animation is improved.
But that can be said for many OVAs that accompanied many TV series's.

I gotta work later on so i opened them up now.
I arranged both batches next to each other for convinience.

Batch1:
Dear matt, thank you for all the goodies, you are right, i'm not much of a whiskey man but im lookin forward to try this old scotch. The Molle Pouches come in really useful, i can fill em with the chocolate and sweets to trade for when shtf. the boonie hat is actually the third boonie in my involuntary collection, though the only milsurp one. The Cummerbund is great, the camo pattern is not visible when the pouches are attached so thats great too. As for the stove, so far ive been a fan of the firebox woodstove, but this seems like a cool gadget ( also why tf you left the price on everything man :D) gf uses gas when camping, so i will try it when hiking with her. The paket of snuff is something else, as a smoker i will give it a try but the 12 gauge lighter will def get its use (also fits really snug in the molle) Thank you so much man! Will shoot you a mail regarding the customs issue but i'd say a 50/50 christmas truce and were good.

Batch 2:
My Santa from le pole du nord,
Thank you for the classy and aestethic box art! I stated no art at all but for the french there must be an exception and im glad u did. Sorry for not including it but i think you posted a picture >>56496540
The leatherbelt is straight up perfect! Thanks man. I think you have a peppermint fetish with all these sweets and the liqour, unfortunately i don't but i WILL try it and think of 1813. The Medal is a nice piece, that war really paved the way to some great years of Prussian state history under Bismarck (until Wilhelm II. fucked it up). All these Patés really look nice, can't wait to try them too. I actually eaten creme marron before and can confirm it's tastyness. The flag came broken as you intended, its now hanging over the entrance to the kitchen to mark the territory you've claimed with your delicacies.
Merci beaucoup!

Merry Christmas /k/!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56506402
Ah, I am glad you like it man. I have no idea how it came so fast, I am surprised myself. Perhaps because it is much lighter than usual and I chose the express option. Also Germany and Austria are both priority postal countries from here and have direct air connections with us.

I had to open your stuff on the 21st as I flew overseas to be with the family for Crimbo.
But I took pictures and will write about it tomorrow.

>Saint John
Always a classic. Good move for the door.
>The Francs
Yes I really like their style. Also, I do hate the Antichrist.
>The arrow
I like homemade stuff and I wanted to use a bodkin head but I couldn't my box with the arrowheads in the shed. So a 7.69 did the trick. It was shot by an ARM1 from Arsenal Kazanlak, so with a homemade touch.
>the bead
I was in a hurry and forgot to write about it. It's called a Martenitsa. It's a custom here, the tradition links it to the Thracians and then the Bulgars. On the first of March for the feast of Baba Marta,everyone gives them around as a symbol of health and luck. Then when the wearer sees the first stork or blooming tree, it is taken off and put on a tree branch for it to bear fruits.

Merry /K/hristmas mate and thanks again for the presents.

Slings were used by every army that had access to devoted slinging populations for as long as those traditions existed. They were used from neolithic times to the Renaissance, and heavy slingers dominated pre-warbow archers.
A fist sized rock or a lead weight of equivalent mass moving at over 100MPH hits like a blow from a hammer, and was capable of causing injury through better armor than bows of a draw weight under 100#. Not only are there accounts of slingstones and lead sling bullets penetrating significantly into human bodies, but we know for a fact it happened because there were recorded medical procedures and tools for attempting to remove them.
Now heavy slings require years to become proficient with (just like bows), and lighter slings are less effective. Even the mightiest Longbows and Arbalests were always niche, a useful support to your main force most of the time, and Slings were no different.
The advantage of slings over bows (for both the light ones kind of suck and the strong ones take forever to train) was in Logistics: While lead, carved stones and even clay projectiles were superior, ammunition, rough stones could be used to resupply if necessary, and even the hand crafted Sling ammo was far easier to make and supply than arrows. Slings could also be replaced for almost nothing, and could be issued to men who were only passable in their use for little extra bulk in case they needed to make do as skirmishers.

Depending on the door, you may very well not need to breach the lock mechanism at all, most interior doors could be breached by blasting away material above and below the mechanism and then kicking it to break the rest of the door away from it. You can also do this with regular shot, without a breaching cup even, though a proper cup and breaching load will be better suited.

>>56513706
>Just imagine: underbarrel .410 bolt action
Setting aside that .410 Bore would probably be on the modest size even for a cheap hollow-core door, Masterkeys are already a thing. They never really stuck, because entry teams prefer just having some short little gun hanging on their gear rather than have it add weight to their rifle. The KAC one also adds a fair bit of weight with the M203 style mounting bracket, you could use some setup to attach something like it to a rail, but NOT having it attached to your rifle would make your rifle lighter and less cumbersome, and would only add the modest weight of a plastic pistolgrip to the shotgun (which now doesn't need that rail, so you could skip that for whatever minor difference in weight that would make).

I think it's because it's perceived as too weak nowadays.
I used to carry a Walther PPK in .32 auto but sold it and started carrying a Glock 19x.
This one time I decided to check if a .32 can penetrate this old tabletop that was laying around in my garage. I was gonna use it as firewood.
The tabletop was 5cm thick (2 inches for my American friends).
I fired 8 shots into it from about 25 meters and none of them actually made it through, some were just barely poking out the back.
I remember old myths of people surviving gunshots because their belt buckle, wallet or phone slowed the bullet down just enough to not cause any serious damage and I think they were talking about a .32. It just seems too weak.
Of course, if that's that only thing you can shoot well, it's definitely than the .45 you leave at home.

>>56508671
Its linked to Napoleon, because he relied on French Army being able to outmarch its opponents. Therefore he made soldiers to carry their own provisions and setting up bivouacs using their greatcoats as shelter/sleeping bag, instead of proper camps with tents, which would have to be carried on wagons that slowed down traditional armies. Even before him the French Republican Armies resorted to these methods, but that was out of necessity more than by design. They just didnt have the resources to support large trains. Also the new Republican officers and rankers were not accustomed to rely on camp followers and servants as much as the the nobles and professional soldiers.
Napoleon separated logistics from the fighting component, main forces were tasked to destroy the enemy in decisive battle as quick as possible, for a limited time living off the land and carried provisions, and after them went separate units that set up the depots and ensured the delivery of supplies. It worked very well in Western Europe, but fucked him good in Russia, when supply lines got overextended and land was too poor and sparsely populated to provide for the huge army which was unable to engage in decisive battle, because Russians just kept retreating.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56506962
The length of trigger travel and length of trigger reset are large. That's fine for a full auto bullet hose which is what the p90 was meant to be.

In semi-auto, all that trigger movement and reset slow down the rate of fire drastically vs. something like an AR with an upgraded trigger pack. So, you're actually going to get a slower fire rate from an anemic round whose singular merit was to sustain a cone of bullets.

The p90 was originally designed for military truck drivers that were not expected to be fighting. They were considered less skilled and needed a defensive weapon they could have on them in the truck. The p90 came along with a 50 round capacity intended for longer bursts in a cone of fire. It's a good design for that.

In semi-auto, the trigger severely detracts from it's merit and the round is under powered versus other shoulder fired weapons.

If you compare it to a draco or an ar-15, you can put more, more powerful rounds on target quicker. The p90 may have a certain cool factor but it is not "good" in the context of other options that happen to also be cheaper.

>tl:dr >>56506967 this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56514198
Because right now, there isn't really a place for them in Ukraine. PMCs like Executive Outcomes were (and still are) common in African conflicts because the local state militaries are often poorly trained and poorly equipped to deal with their security challenges (i.e. terrorist and guerilla groups). PMCs were also common in Iraq and Afghanistan because they were able to do certain jobs (i.e. security for diplomats, base security, private business security) more efficiently than the US Armed Forces.

Right now, Ukraine has a well-equipped, well-armed state military, has no shortage of both domestic and foreign volunteers, and has no need for security to protect diplomats or private businesses. Once the War dies down and reconstruction efforts ramp up, I expect PMCs to become a very common sight in Ukraine.

>>56505485
As a range toy it's pretty fun. The sights are very fine, basically designed for target shooting with multiple aperture styles (open notch or closed circle) to choose from and minutely adjustable for elevation and windage. A poor choice for the kind of quick snap shooting necessary in modern combat, but for taking your time they're fine.

I find the straight-wristed "S"-stock to be less ergonomic than the pistol-gripped "C"-stock; it has a lower comb and less purchase for your rear hand to control the rifle. However since my collection is WW1-oriented it's the stock I keep on this rifle because it gives it the era-appropriate look.

>>56511283
Suping up a normal gun can be done in production, since production is literally bent towards normal guns. But when you get to standard division, it just doesn't cut it anymore. The weight of the frame and larger magazines give an advantage that just can't be made up. Honestly, for standard, you just need to bite the bullet and get a dedicated pistol.

If you're already shooting competitions and you enjoy it, then I'd say get the competition specialized guns. If you haven't even shot a comp yet, then bring whatever you have that is production legal to a few matches to get a feel for what you like or don't like. And by the way, you sound American, so you're not really going to find any IPSC matches, they'll all be USPSA.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I am out innawoods and want to build a fire I will start with very small diameter twigs. The dead ends of pine tree branches, for example, that are about the diameter of a pencil led. I will add twigs of increasing size, the diameter of a pencil , for example, and increase the amount of wood and size of the branches until I have the fire I want.
I say all of this because I have built hundreds of fires in all conditions over the years. I have a nice wood fire going in my Fisher Papa Bear wood stove right now. I am currently burning a mix of seasoned red oak and white oak I harvested about 3 years ago.
Anyway, I do not have anything against batoning but I rarely do it. Just never need to. Is it because I live in Appalachia and fire wood is so plentiful ? so i never have to baton to build a fire ?
In these knife threads someone always brings up batoning like it is some critical knife performance measure. Which is fine but it puzzles me since i never need to do it. It would be a waste of time and energy for me to baton because the size wood I need is always available.
Anyway, it is 5 degrees F outside, snow is covering the yard, I have a nice fire going in my wood stove. The power and all utilities are on. I have a nice cup of coffee and the sun is about to come up this morning. I am truly blessed here in my Appalachian refuge and wish the best for all of you all wherever you may be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
to build a reasonably modern fighter, you need reasonably modern industries in a number of fields:
>large scale composites manufacturing
>radar and electronics
>turbine engines
etc

many of these fields either have little real civilian use, ie 24" aesa radars, or fields that are completely dominated by a handful of foreign juggernauts, ie turbines. if these industries don't already exist and there's few countries where they do, they would have to be built up entirely at government expense and probably be sustained entirely at government expense because there's no real market they could break into to sustain themselves. foreign sales of the fighter would be difficult because your reasonably modern 4.5 gen fighter is competing against a colossal used market of f-16s etc, an equally colossal new market of higher end fighters being produced at volumes you can't compete with, and little political clout to get it done with because weapons purchases are a political thing.

fighters also very much suffer from a better-is-better condition. a little worse is sometimes an unrecoverable deficiency.

occasionally there's a country like turkey that can take a decent stab at it, but they've been positioning themselves for decades to gain the ability to do so.

It's really fucking expensive, and not just financially, and it takes a long fucking time to get there.
Not only do you need aerospace expertise, but also materials science, computer science, manufacturing, and the ability to scale.
A government must first build up domestic industry and the relevant sciences academia, or provide the conditions in which they would flourish. They need to be able to buy a lot of them over a fairly long period of time to bring the costs down to something acceptable. The initial R&D alone requires the best in their respective fields in the world, who must be paid commensurately, and who will also need the facilities required to develop, test, manufacture, and assemble exotic materials, AND x-planes to test them.
Only the US and China can feasibly sustain aerospace programs on their own. Allied nations splitting the R&D, research, tech development, and production eases the cost burden, and having other allies buy it brings it in reach of second powers jointly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The US expended huge resources on the Manhattan Project. The biggest bottleneck was U ore isotope separation.

It seems possible that the Nazi bomb effort was focused in a manner more suitable to their resources and strengths. They didn't have access to lots of Uranium ore, while the US flew in large amounts from Belgian Congo.

I wonder if they instead persued Thorium 232 bombardment to make U 233, and used skilled German machining to make very small bombs to make up for the relative paucity of fissionable material.

Some German nuclear material was on a U boat en route to Japan when the Nazis surrendered. This was turned over to the US, and it's interesting to consider if this material found its way into one of the weapons used on Japan.

Overall I find the idea of pre-Alamogordo nuclear detonations to be plausable but not proven. Classifying and surpressing easier or alternate paths to a nuclear weapon is a wise policy for the future of above-ground cities. No finer place for sure, downtown.

If an officer got butthurt after being yelled at for some safety issue and complained, the officer would be the one reprimanded. Enlisted coxswains are endorsed from the O5/O6 level after a rigorous qual process so they already have the command's backing.
The BM warrant specialty (BOSN) is incredibly competitive, respected, and fills many command positions afloat and ashore
AFAIK the navy won't let a vessel of any size get underway with only enlisted crew, because there's no trust there.

posts.com:
1/2 Discuss only the most plausible, near future firearm alternatives.
Treat it as a thought experiment, not requiring a huge improvement over conventional guns, but being at least half as effective for stopping a man and man portable.
WHAT DOESN'T WORK
~Visible wavelength, non pulsed lasers will blind everyone in the area at killing wattages, have huge energy and cooling demands, will cause atmospheric plasma blooming at killing wattages and conditions like fog or dust can degrade effect rapidly.
~Railguns require breakthroughs in rapid discharge capacitors and energy storage, while also suffering from arcing between the rails and projectile.
~battery tech for killing energy railguns and lasers would require advancements of such magnitude that it's likely not "near future".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56510085
2/2 PLAUSIBLE N.F. EXAMPLES
While requiring technological advancement, these concepts require less over the horizon breakthroughs.
~Elecrolaser
Electrolasers pulse a very brief but very intense laser beam, breaking the air down to a plasma channel through which it passes a killing electric charge. The design been pulsed allows for more modest energy demands. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrolaser
~Chemical energy laser
Chemical energy pulsed lasers utilize a contained reaction to pump the crystal, typically a flash or detonation. The Soviet Laser Pistol is a real world demonstration of the concept, using zirconium flash bulb "laser cartridges" to produce a beam for blinding optics, no batteries required. With modern material science and capacitor technology, we could produce more powerful pulses using the a similar concept, likely using a small capacitor to vaporize a tiny pellet in the cartridge, producing plasma or other methods of detonation to pump the laser. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_laser_pistol
~ECT Gun
ECT guns use a conventional propellant ingited by an electrochemical plasma reaction, resulting in a more optimal burn and improved ballistics. This is almost certainly the future of large guns, at present we can get 140mm conventional gun energies with a 120mm ECT gun.
~Marauder/spooky plasma
Not much is known about the Marauder project other than it could project rings of plasma with devastating explosive effects on target. It was classified back in the day and may or may not be a dead end. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/MARAUDER
~Centrifugal gun
Centrifugal guns have always been and likely will always be a meme, but less so with the mass development of small brushless motors, and so fit the parameters of this thread. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centrifugal_gun

Post what you know bros.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I live alone in a large house and have motions sensors in all the rooms rigged to an alarm with a speaker next to my bed, if any motion is detected a loud voice alerts me to which room it’s in. I’ve had this system for over a year and not a single false alarm so any time it goes off I trust that it’s an actual person. Anyway I was asleep at 2:40 AM last night and get woken up to it saying there’s been motion detected by my sliding glass doors, 2 floors below me. I immediately wake up and roll over to my nightstand and unlock my pistol safe holding my Glock, I grab the gun and turn off my white noise generator and sit there for a minute or two to listen for any sounds of movement in my house. Can’t hear anything during this time but I am completely overrun with adrenaline and notice the grip of my gun is drenched in sweat. I turn my weapon light on and slowly begin to clear my house (I’m the only one here so not worried about pointing WML at friendlies), I get to the sliding doors and there’s nothing abnormal with no signs of activity so it was a false alarm… But HOLY SHIT the adrenaline bros, I realize how much harder it would have been to accurately shoot my gun in that state, the sweat, the shaking, etc. How do you even train for this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56512044
Extremely repetitive training under semi stressful conditions. Training conditions can’t really replicate the stress but they can establish a gross motor response to do the right thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56515028
You're unaware that there were plenty of cruise missile developments way before Tomahawk and ALCM missiles took off, not even counting the whole class of anti-ship missiles.

US developed and deployed multiple cruise missiles in the strategic nuclear role, largely before they were replaced by ballistic missiles. These include Regulus submarine cruise missiles and Snark the intercontinental cruise missile. Even after the advent of ballistic missiles US B-52s carried Hound Dog supersonic cruise missiles, which were deployed before US involvment in vietnam was a thing. Hound Dog stayed on alert for 13 years and the air launched ballistic missiles SRAM from the 70s replaced it before the appearance of the ALCM. The reason these weren't used is because they didn't have the accuracy to be practical without nuclear warheads as well as being very expensive strategic weapons that contained lots of classified tech. Hound Dog, for example, used early radar absorbent treatment in order to reduce its detectability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56511013
To be fair, the VAST majority of those were smaller light carriers or escort carriers, and even the larger fleet carriers pale in comparison to a modern supercarrier.

45 of the US's carriers were Bogue-class escort carriers that cost less than $5M each in 1942. (about $92M in 2022)
They only carried ~20-24 aircraft and had less than 15,000 ton displacement when fully loaded.

The US also had 50 Casablanca-class escort carriers, which were at ~$6M each in 1942 or around $110M in 2022. They similarly had only a ~12,000 ton displacement when fully loaded with ~27 aircraft.

The larger fleet carriers of the Essex-class were the only carriers that really cost a substantial amount, at around $75M in 1942 which is around $1.4B in 2022. But even the Essex-class only displaced 35,000 tons and carried 90-100 aircraft.


The most recent US aircraft carrier, the Gerald R. Ford-class has a 100,000+ ton displacement, and costs around $15B each, more than 10x what the Essex-class cost.


A single carrier today costs FAR more than what any single carrier did back in WWII, even if we account for inflation. With the eventual plan to field 10 GRF-Class carriers, you could argue that it's equivalent to 100 Essex-class fleet carriers from WWII, which was 4x the actual number the US had during WWII.

So by that metric, the 10 carriers the US operates during modern "peacetime" are 4x more of an economic show of force than the US's entire aircraft carrier naval assets in WWII.

So basically years ago before I met my ex I collected anything that was cheap or was an oddity at a good price. At one point I probably had 50+ guns including several Tec 9s, MAC clones, Saturday Night Specials, etc. Then my life went to shit, she ran up credit cards and everything else, and I sold a lot of shit to secure us a house that ended up just being my house because things went south. This included most of my firearms, anything that wasn't sentimental besides a few essentials.

I built myself back up best I could, and now I mostly focus on higher quality pieces that I find at great deals. I still buy a few cheap shitters sometimes, but I'm at the stage in my life where I'd rather spend for quality with items that either make sense or have some kind of oddity appeal because I haven't outgrown my eccentric hipsterism. I rarely sell anything anymore, because there are guns I've sold in years past that I really wish I still had and won't get the opportunity without spending crazy money (like the $1600 FS2000 gen 1 I got in 2009).

>>56480442

Harbor freight has good deals on the cheap black tape, but the blue scotch is pricey but is great stuff. Comes in handy for jungle taping mags and when you've got some cheap gun that has stripped grips screws and don't care to spend money fixing it. I also like slick and smooth over stippled, so that's why I use electrical over something like grip or other fabric tape.

An AR in .223/5.56, a shotgun (semi or pump), a handgun, and a .22 rifle like a 10/22. A .22 handgun can be nice too. Gives you basically everything you'd want.
>AR for HD and hunting medium game/furbearers (unless gay state)
>shotgun for HD and hunting game (depending on barrel length, choke)
>handgun for self defense
>.22 rifle for small game and cheap practice/plinking
>.22 handgun for practice/plinking
Only other thing you might want is a small air rifle for home practice depending on where you live. Now, "collection" can mean different things to different people. If by "collection", you mean "what should I buy first for general use?", then what I said. If by "collection", you mean surplus collection, that's harder.

Russia is the small block at the 4 o'clock position (green section).

Being cut off the primary importer of your primary export is pretty economically catastrophic, especially when you're fighting a high-intensity war. It's even worse though because Russia was extremely reliant on the import of "high technologies" from the West. The cessation of such imports for military purposes in 2014 was one of the reasons that new weapons systems like the T-14 and Su-57 never got off the ground and Russia had to just keep upgrading all of their old Soviet-inherited hardware instead. Now the complete cession of such imports entirely mean that the civilian sector in Russia will very quickly start stalling as well. China and India can't entirely make up the shortfall in imports or exports without endangering their own relationship with the West, nor would they be inclined to as Russia still represents a potential threat to them. Right now, Russia is cooking the books to the point where the books are on fire but that can only go for so long, especially when everyone KNOWS that you're cooking the books.

posts.com: Here's the problem about most discussions on weapons: Most of the people today engaged in the discussion are not men of violence. It's no different than having a discussion about building homes with but a few if any in the discussion being carpenters. Much of the discussion necessitates that it is spent educating the participants, while letting their egos shut down debate especially on the more critical counterintuitive subjects. I've come to the conclusion that /k serves more to neuter the populations understanding of weapons and violence rather than to advance that understanding. That said, this thread in particular has highlighted my observations. I've seen and been in many violent situations with edged and bludgeoning weapons in both open and tight quarters. Anyone who works in or has been confined to a violent American state prison for over a decade has this experience. My experience is with the Texas prison units known as gladiator farms. A dagger is the prison equivalent of an M4. Any offender armed with an effective dagger is nigh unstoppable while indoors. It would take time and special conditions for the staff to bring a firearm to bear. If outdoors, it's over in a second as the picket towers have M4 rifles with optics. A dagger is highly effective for what it's designed to do: Multiple deep and fatal stabs in quick succession. It goes in and out of flesh quickly and fairly easily due to its design. Its shape also induces far more trauma than a spike. It is a very good assassination weapon: Easily concealed, quick to bear, fatal wounds inflicted in less than a second. That's the only purpose of a dagger, it is by no means a utility knife of any sort, its a killing device under specific conditions. Such is the case of many weapons. Can you hunt white tail deer with .338 Lalpa? Technically, yes, but WHY? Especially if you had the goal of harvesting that deers meat. Weapons are tools. Tools are designed for the work asked of them. Cont.

posts.com: But yes. Imagine a trench that is about one meter wide at the height of your shoulders, narrowing down to half as wide at the bottom. Can you swing a short sword (like a 1866 Chasepot yatagan bayonet, or 1891 Argentina Mauser bayonet, popular among criollo knife fighters for the size and curved crossguard) in such kind of a narrow corridor comfortably, or turn it around for a good thrust? I doubt it. So they had to cut down bayonets (Arditi daggers made of old 1870 Vetterli bayonets), make short bayonets from the start (Demag G98 dagger bayonets with crank handle), or bring in hunting knives (german nickers, various Sheffield products), design simple fighting knives from zero (Grabendolch, Nahkampfmesser), or bring in some ethnic classic (kukris, bolos, russian and finnish puukkos were widespead during Russian Civil War and WWII, navaja style knives were common in France and Italy during WWI). >>56511432
I think I'm going to say blasphemy, but Ka-Bar is more of a history need fetish these days. Here are some complaints I've heard:
- Lousy sheath. Yes, two-piece stitched leather sheath is a common design seen all over the world, however it has downsides, for example, a knife is kept in place only by a button which may open when you move through the bushes and the knife might fall out. And when, for example, you wear large backpacks with belts, you might have troubles with accessing your knife. And when you fall from anywhere, like, off the bike in an accident, the knife may cut through the sheath and wound you. Better alternative would be antique bottleneck style sheath hanging freely on the loop, as featured in many ethnic and ethnic-themed designs, such as puukkos, yakut blades, Helle Viking and Peltonen M95.
- The handle. It's assembled with large leather pieces. It feels relatively good in hand, it's better for cold environments than G10 or other synthetic materials. However leather requires care, can get worn faster than wood or bone, it soaks so the tang might get rusty, also it's round rather than barrel-shaped, so edge alignment in the dark might suffer. Why would they make those leather pieces large instead of using multiple small pieces anyway?

Battle plans (effectively assault approach routes and axes) are planned on tablets using navigation programmes and Google Earth views. ‘Different colours identify different assault groups. Each group has its own route and determination of where each fighter in each of the assault groups should be…the leaders receive the programme of their attack, and how he and each of his fighters should move through the points. That is, you don’t need to think, you need to check the movement of your group on a tablet or smartphone.’

‘Unlike the Russian Armed Forces, Butisov explains, ‘Wagner’s main means of communication are American radio stations and Motorola repeaters…simple analogue “Baofeng” [Chinese walkie-talkies] are also widely used.’

The short range of these communications necessarily limits the size of attacks. This observation may also be made of the Russian Army. The chief reason why YouTube is saturated with videos showing small unit actions but not battalion actions is constraints imposed by Russian tactical communications that have proved unfit for purpose.

Assault groups are typically ‘8-12 to 30-50 fighters’.

LOOKS like a weakness in their armor is primitive communications and limited ability to adapt on the fly.

You should take him down to the shelter to help pick out the cat, see how he interacts with them in that controlled space. Probably try a kitten as long as he's careful with it, let them play a little. It helps if you end up picking the cat that chooses you, typically one will fixate on you in particular. Best if they see the whole family or most of them so they know more or less what they're getting into.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56447740
Given what you've said, nobody here is qualified to advise you. Seek out professional help from a qualified childhood behavioral psychologist. Start at your school and describe the problem, tell them you're concerned where he picked this fear up and that you suspect it's from his interaction with other children or someone at the school because you can't identify another source. Small lies here can get you free help that the school district is already paid to provide.

Get a professional to talk with your son and try to determine the source. After that question is resolved, then you can figure out how to address it.

Listen to me carefully here, because I am Someone Who Knows The Fuck Out Of These Things: parents who don't know what they're doing will put far more fuck in their childrens' heads than almost anything they will encounter. You have a trust relationship with your child that will screw their head inside out if you get one word out of place.

For the sake of any cats or other pets involved, DO NOT bring a cat or kitten into the house until you get some sort of an evaluation from a specialist in childhood behavior. You are in over your head, get help. Get professional help.

PERIOD.

Incorrect. There is no teaching a dog basic friend or foe concepts. They either have it or they don't. There is like...3 to 5 breeds where they're smart enough to figure these things out on a case-by-case basis, but once they decide HUSKY = BAD it is almost hopeless to try to unteach that, then you have to avoid all huskies.

Years before that. At least now the ping-pong tard has left, with his amazing claims about how he'll solve consistency issues any day now. Same as every other cocksucker before and after him. It can't be done - not in a "DIY" setup. I've never heard of a machine-gun grade, Poudre B or better level of propellant made, and I've been on this for years. Can you make guncotton? You're better off with a home-made needle gun or even a slam-bang, it is much more practical, vastly more reliable. For homemade weapons to be viable on a group level they need to be cheap, reliable and mass producible. Right now what seems to be working relatively well is the FCG 9mk 2 with its guide being Detailed and a lot of documentation being up online,. They've been popping up a lot in places like Myanmar and other arms controlled areas. although it's not perfect, being printed If its body is dropped too hard it will crack, also if it is printed in PLA+ And your shooting A lot of rounds through it or if its too hot where you are, parts will reach glass transition temperature and warp or melt which is dangerous because it could ruin Your head spacing. If you upgrade/get a better printer and print higher temperature materials like abs or Asa that Can be mitigated. a really big component that separates the FCG9 from other designs is the ECM Rifling process which allows you to easily make rifled barrels. To get a low-end FCG9 factory up you probably need like 600$ to get a Basic ender printer, ECM rifling set up, hand tools, Basic Reloading set up, And an optional cheap welder if you wanna go for the welded bolt option. then you just have to Bulk by hardware store components And Springs that you could make but for now, buying them is cheaper and easier. The bar for making them has to get lower and cheaper but still retain Functionality and effectiveness. You may think those 2 fight against each other but that's not true, With the advancing technology in 3-D printing and other tools it will become Cheaper, look at 3d printing in 2012 to now. it is a double edged sword though, because as technology gets better the government also gets the best stuff 1st but You got to take the good with the bad I guess

>>56465975
Military grade munitions repurposed into IEDs was more of an iraqi thing. Afghans are waaaaaay more poor than iraqis, while they weren't above using military grade ordinance as IEDs if they had access to them they were far more likley to try to fire them than use them as IEDs. We typically encountered Ammonium nitrate based devices.

The most common was to spray paint a steel plate with silver spray paint, scrape it off, and repeat to get access to aluminum powder. They would then mix it into the ammonium nitrate and use an improvised blasting cap. I've seen them use about 8 inches of det chord tied into knots, empty 7.62x39 casings filled with flashpowder and crimped shut around an electrical igniter, etc etc.

Typically afghan ieds using this mixture were between 40 to 80 pounds, though we did discover some that were up to 450 pounds. They typically used empty 5 gallon fuel jugs as the casing. Anything lower than 40 pounds was kind of not really effective. The biggest limiting factor for this mixture was that it had to be emplaced relatively shortly before use (about a week prior, preferably 2 to 3 day) because the ammonium nitrate tends to absorb moisture from the air or soil.

I stepped on a 40 pounder and it sorta just floofed a ton of smouldering ammonium nitrate prills all over me. Smelled like literal shit.

>>56459545
>what is the major obstacle that's preventing people from...
Precision. With a few months of the kind of hard work that makes you curse the day of your birth, you'll be able to make something that *looks* like a Sten gun, and fires, and maybe even loads cartridges more often than it doesn't. But going from that to actually having an SMG that has 1 to 200 and not 1 to 5 failure to fire rate is basically impossible without machine-tools (at least a full-sized lathe). That's starting at >$3000. I've never seen proof to the contrary. I'm not saying it's literally impossible - but the amount of years it will take you to hand-craft a functional self-loader is far better invested into buying the machinery. Then you'll be able to breeze through it in a couple of weeks (if you already have your blueprints), then fine-tune for several months, and it's possible you'll get and SMG that could actually compete with WW2 surplus (if you're a good designer and machinist).
Human hands and hand-held power tools simply cannot replicate the precision of even mediocre machines. Yes, 2nd gen SMG's look "simple". But they aren't. If you want to make a slam-bang or a pipebomb - sure, that's doable. If you want to make self-loading weapons that you could actually bring into fucking combat and not just plinking in the woods - you will have to become a machinist, with all of the severe costs that implies. It's why you almost never see weapons manufactured from scratch in rogue stays or partisan movements - and the few SMG's that they have are visibly made using machine-tools. Good example is the Chechen "Borz" series of SMG's. Sure, they managed to produce them immediately prior to and for a few months during the First Chechen War. But as soon as the Russians have flattened the Red Hammer factory and captured Grozny, that production stopped - forever. Same with ISIS. Gunsmithing DIY is unfortunately a meme, it's why there is so little content in these threads, throughout the years.

I blued the barrel, then put the upper receiver in the oven, then used a can of air duster held upside down to get the barrel really really cold and used a dowel and mallet to tap it in while it was in a vice. I measured headspace periodically until it was more or less right, then drilled it and used a bottle-jack press to force the pin in. I then 3D printed the receiver and assembled it. I serialized it because it was a gift for my dad, who Intended to SBR it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56468206
Single-action break guns are much, much easier. Yes. If you go on any gun-making forum you'll see literally hundreds of threads of people making single-shot rifles, slamming up against one or another machining wall, and then eventually finishing one months or years later. But almost all of them finish the build, don't blow their faces off, and get a gun that performs as advertised. The feeding mechanisms and repeatability are the thing that always, always kicks your ass making a gun from scratch. Even rifling is less of a pain in the ass.

One of the extremely cool things you can do with a 3d printer, however, is make an auto-filing machine that runs off of a hand drill. This will shave literal days' worth of work off of a from-scratch build. In general they let you create masters for casting parts of much more effective machine tools, and low-precision tools you can use to make much more precise ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56468687
The answer is always gas-operated rotating/tilting bolt, and I recommend long-stroke, not short-stroke but that's preference. There's nothing wrong with flapper-lock gas operation or other gas action designs, but I recommend rotation, as it's the most well-studied. Gas operation is very, very forgiving in its modification and tuning, much more so than any delayed blowback, let alone the cursed r*coil operation which should not be mentioned outside of shotguns or HMG's.
Specifically, gas operating rotating bolt is vastly superior to G3's *roller* delayed blowback, the most complex and finicky of the common delaying mechanisms. It is not simple, it is not easy, it is one of the hardest non-r*coil operated actions. Read about the development of Stg 45 and Mp 5; it takes an immense amount of prototyping and extreme precision to manufacture - don't even try this. If you ever want to try delayed blowback (I know I wouldn't, except maybe gas-delayed pistols), you should only try the lever-delay, that one is sort-of-simple, but the amount of precision milling operations you'll have to do is not significantly different from those on the AK BCG. Yes it doesn't have a gas system but it's not as if that's some kind of meme magical supercomputer clockwork time machine. If you can machine a bolt-carrier group, you can definitely make a gas system, even an adjustable one, especially for something as "simple" as an AK-style long-stroke action.
You sound like you don't have any tooling yet and haven't even made a straight-blowback yet. I recommend you do that first, it sounds like you don't yet grasp the immense complexity of such a project. It is not different from designing a roadworthy, durable motorcycle or a modern kitchen applience; this is not a project for people who don't love mechanical engineering.

Anon, before that shooting, a lot of posters here and elsewhere insisted that straight blowback guns would handle black powder and extremely dirty ammo better than anything else. The idea was that black powder just fouled up the receiver and moving parts, and therefore the simplicity and heavy bolt of a straight blowback gun would allow it to blast through the fouling for much longer than anything else. A lot of talk immediately after the shooting even blamed the shooter's inability to produce consistent in spec mags for all his issues before people finally started realizing that bolt opening while gasses from extremely dirty propellant are still in the barrel = chamber getting fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56481594
That's just a lack of basic understanding of self-loading firearms. The bit about blasting through fouling could hold some truth to it, but only if
1)the amount of extra fouling each shot is relatively small and doesn't accumulate too quickly
2)the fouling has somewhere to go
The second principle is easily enough provided for with various types of recesses in the receiver, but the first one is completely impossible for non-recoil operated actions, doubly so for unlocked ones - and straight blowback is the worst of them all. Not only do you need to limit the amount of residue - even for that amount you'll need A LOT of recoiling mass to reciprocate during action, more than even most straight blowbacks provide. It's why the only known actions to operate reliably with blackpowder are the original Maxim gun system and the long-recoil operated shotguns like Browning Auto-5.

Depends on how hard you want to make it. Even old revolvers required a lathe and mill. Check out this series: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=80wm9GY7IwI
But if you want to simplify it and skip the aesthetics you cold get away with a lot of jank involving tubes and flat sheets of steel. Pic related is a 4mm Flobert revolver made by a Russian youtuber, sadly the video was probably taken down because of the DIY gun rules. The cylinder was a bunch of tubes held together and soldered in place, the indexing mechanism was a pin acting as a plunger with the rip rounded off, connected to the trigger bar. By pulling the trigger, the plunger would enter one of the chambers and prevent the cylinder from rotating during a firing.

>>56466137
I've had a theory on that for a while now. I believe it's because of the numbers of trainer rifles over here that are virtually indistinguishable from normal arisakas to the average mook at least. It would be a liability issue for any ammo manufacturer when you get a dozen or so retards per year trying to sue you for "defective ammo that blew up their gun and injured them". Every time it happens, their case hinges upon if there is enough of the gun left to prove beyond a shadow of a doubt it was a trainer. Every time they can't do this is a time where they pay out of their ass and hell, every time they can do it is a time where they still have to pay a lawyer and court fees. So they approach it with a "why risk it" mentality and don't bother.

posts.com:
>>56481622
>not much bigger than a man
>pod in OP is at least the size of 4 or maybe 8 men combined
The ODST pods from Halo are roughly the same dimensions: they weighed around 500kg, operated on electronics, had to use thrusters to survive impact, and were prone to failure. Fiction aside, they're dumb to use compared to conventional paratroopers for a number of reasons.
Dropping 60-200~ car-sized disposable cockpits, heavily dependent on a gorillion moving parts and radio-dependent software, over enemy territory from orbit isn't a great idea for deploying soldiers. No rational insurgent/spec ops group would want to be shipped in a disposable rocket, leaving major heat/radar trails, with a fairly high chance it'll fuck up given the nature of shit entering the atmosphere.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56512945
it is genuinely a good rifle, im not just saying that because my company made it. they're incredibly accurate and the barrels will easily last tens of thousands of rounds. we've got an old DD5 that's had 65k rounds through the original barrel and only had to replace the bolt once.
the issues with the DD5 are primarily logistical. if something breaks, you have to send it to us to be fixed since we don’t sell the individual parts for some reason. the parts are also proprietary, so you can't really do your own work on it anyway. the barrel and receiver/handguard design is meant to be able to somewhat quickly swap barrels with minimal zeroing loss, but since you can't buy the barrels to swap calibers it's pointless.
that being said, unless you're absolutely retarded there's almost no way you should end up breaking something major. as mentioned before the barrel will probably last as long as you will, and the bolt carrier group is made in house by us so its just as, if not more durable than our AR-15 BCG. the lower parts are the same as any other AR-10 and the lower itself is Armalite spec, so you can use the lower to fire any Armalite/KAC/LMT/LWRCI uppers you may have or vice versa

if you rush at someone with your head down they can attack you all kinds of ways. they can stab the back of your neck and possibly even sever your spine if the knife is big enough. they can stab from beneath or the side and still hit the front/side of your neck, face, chest. a knife can even penetrate the skull as well (google image it, many examples).

when did I ever say you won't get cut? the concept "it's hard not to get cut in a knife fight" does not automatically lead to the conclusion " you should just run in recklessly with your head down, pray they non-vitally stab your back, and then go for killshots."

it's an OK strategy if some dude is already stabbing your grandma and you have no choice but to go all in. it's an OK strategy if you are in a crazy military housefighting situation and you need to kill a guy ASAP and can't afford to play safe.

but on the streets, in a situation like the OP where dudes are circling each other and shit, it's not the best strategy. I am not claiming to be some knife master, but I've studied perspectives from many different knife users; schools of thought like Kali and tanto-ryu, military techniques, and modern practical stuff from people like Craig Douglas, Mike Donvito, etc. Not because I want to be a street ninja, it's just fun to learn these things. And none of them are going to say to do what you're talking about. You certainly may still get cut even if you play it safer but you are still LESS LIKELY TO DIE, that is the point.

>>56509424
>Less volume under the bullet
Once again, the bullet isn't stuck immovably in that position. The reduced volume doesn't matter until the primer goes off, at which point there isn't less volume under the bullet anymore. This whole "seating depth affects pressure" is one of those old wives' tales, oft repeated yet utterly false.
