posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56513887
If you use subsonic ammunition then yes the sound of the action will likely be most all of what is heard.

If you use supersonic ammo the report will still be significantly quieter but there will still be a supersonic crack.

Subsonic ammo has its place, but assuming you are using 5.56 which is a very velocity dependent round when it comes to its effectiveness, you may want to carry more supersonic rounds rather than subs.

The most important feature of a suppressor is that is almost entirely eliminates flash, and can make it harder to pinpoint your firing position, rather than only reducing the decibels heard.

I have used bolt/break action suppressed guns and with subsonic ammo they are extremely fucking quiet, sometimes to he point where the loudest noise that you hear is the wiz of the bullet off the terrain or sound of it hitting the target if you are up close. This is heavily dependent on your weapon and ammunition choice.

Does this warrant using a bolt gun over a semi auto tho? No I don’t think so unless you are absolutely trying to be as quiet as fucking possible for some reason, but more importantly you need to have the versatility to be effective in a non stealth situation even when stealth is your goal.

If you are using SuperSonics out of a suppressed semi auto rifle, you are still significantly quieter than the vast majority of other fags

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56416298
I'm very tempted to buy a stocked Marauder pistol in .22 for squirrels, I just need to get some other guns first. I think I'm going to get a .22lr suppressor for hunting, then a PCP, despite the fact that the other way around would probably make more sense. Wait times for stamps are a bitch, though, so the sooner I start the process, the better. I have other air rifles, though, so it's a niche already partially filled. One partially filled by the Swarm, which I wish were smaller, but I love the quick loading. The other partially filled by the 1377, which I wish was mag fed, a pcp, and .22. You know, basically a Marauder with a stock.

I figure that buying a marauder with a decent scope will allow me to fill a role with what would otherwise would only be able to be filled by a takedown or an SBR. Pistols (firearms) wouldn't fill the role either as semi auto .22lr pistols are illegal to hunt with in this state despite semi auto .22lr rifles being totally fine. Bring a Marauder in a small hard (or well padded) case and if no foxes turn up while I'm lugging around my .223, I can at least take it out to shoot some squirrels or maybe even groundhogs. Solves a problem I have, choosing what to take on a specific day. I can take a semi auto .22lr rifle as well as a .223 for fox, but it's hell on the back having to also bring all my other junk, including a little take-down seat if it's wet and cold out.

>>56416316
>anyone calling for a PCP ban
>anyone calling for an air rifle ban
Would be news to me. Already have a couple air rifles, just no PCP. My latest is the Swarm, which IMO is a genius design, if a hair retarded due to the scope mount being so high. PCP soon; I just wish there were more reviews on budget pumps for the tanks. Everyone ignores those, and it's a little concerning considering I have to rely on them to fill it.

>>56398753
I've posted this little guy before, but this is my first gun pic with him. He usually doesn't sit still long enough for one of these.
If anyone recognizes him, I have a little update on his health situation. He's got FIP, basically kitty covid. Lymph nodes swollen, liver swollen to double it's normal size, jaundiced, etc. We have him on some experimental treatment, isn't FDA approved yet. Seems to be working so far, he's regained normal color in his nose and the other cat isn't treating him like he's sick anymore. Lymph nodes going down too. This was just after the first shot of the stuff, the treatment is supposed to take a few months to clear all this up. He doesn't like needles as we've found, so we've ordered some pills of the same stuff that can be broken up in his soft food. Those come in tomorrow.
He hasn't really changed in his normal behaviors, so I think he's gonna pull through. This treatment has like an 80% to near 100% success rate, percentage of failure just means it won't work. This should work though since he's reacting to it.

>>56509283
He had several innovations:
1) the grand battery and brass cannon (he was an artillery specialist)
2) the corps formation, which eventually was copied by everyone
And additionally made use of or encouraged some other innovations by others
3) the headquarters staff
4) logistics
5) skirmishers
And politically managed to obtain the use of a large number of
6) conscripts

However he wasn't perfect and was notably deficient in
1) selecting and training marshals, some of whom made mistakes that cost him key battles and arguably led to his downfall
2) naval strategy, where he was a relative novice vs the British
3) copying certain inventions such as the Baker rifle and Shrapnel shell
4) made a massive mistake in Russia losing the cream of the French Army
And
5) became relatively slow, uninspired and overconfident to the point of arrogance towards the end, exemplified by his very middling performance at Waterloo

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56498109
Plotwise? It made no sense. I understand why it was necessary, but I feel like it could've been done more cleanly.

Gamewise? Power creep.

Prior to the Clan Invasion, the primary gameplay mechanic was heat management. With the arrival of the Clans, you now had a new mechanic of quantity vs. quality. Fedcom CW is the point where the quantity/quality equation began to flatten out; at the same time, heat loads go down and heat sinking goes up. You've now removed the two main gameplay mechanics and replaced them with one: proper positioning. Guess what other tabletop games are based on this? That's right, all of them, and many of them are way faster and easier to play with far less record keeping.

When the lines began blurring between IS and Clan tech, Battletech did actually die. I realize that there's still a game called Battletech and some people like it, but they like it because it plays so much differently than grogtech. That leaves me wondering why they started playing in the first place.

>also the new mechs look like chopped ass fucktown

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56505629
Depends on the state, but for the most part it's Laissez-faire in the majority of Successor States. The Ares Convention basically was a way to enforce the ruling houses as the status quo, along with creating a glorified NuRoman "Equites" class; those being Mechwarriors. Of course, once the Camerons bit it everyone disregarded what the Ares Convention was originally about (stopping nukes and constant warship orbital bombardments) but kept the part of neofeudalism. to elaborate...

>Lyran Commonwealth/Alliance/House Steiner
Steiners are busy playing the part of puppet masters to all the dumb trustfund babies that inherited a noble title like "General". For the most part, they're hands off to the average mook outside of Skye, who's been a black sheep in the commonwealth since it's inception.

>Free Worlds League/House Marik
Ancapistan with each microstate essentially trying to each other before their bigger neighbors muster enough forces to come knocking on their border. The Director General (Often a Marik, not always, but often.) has to herd cats and bail them out of the stupid shit they do. If you want to be the most "free" in the IS, the FWL's for you. (Also Thomas Halas will be missed. ;_;7)

>Federated Suns
"Father Knows Best" at it's worst. Though, there's a shit ton of podunk backwaters and Amish colonies that basically don't do anything and often do whatever they want anyways. There was also a breakaway state called the "Filtvelt Coalition" that was basically filled with Aussie Bogans and American Rednecks. Literacy was nigh nonexistant and the state was too poor to do much outside of make a few militias (which they couldn't paint Orange half the time, their state's color)

(cont)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56505629
Well, considering that BT liberally cribbed from actual history, perhaps you should crack open some books at look at the incredible weirdness that really did happen. They're not making most of this stuff up whole cloth; they're just filing off the serial numbers. The Mongol Hordes? It's pretty blatant. War of the Roses? Yup. Officers appointed because they're nobles, and not because they actually know how to lead men? Check. An entire system where everybody officially is a subject of the king, but unofficially does whatever they want within the limits of what they can get away with. Hoo boy.

That's a large part of what makes BT lore special; it's grounded in history, rather than just making crude generalizations up whole cloth. People... people never change.

It shouldn't have been; at least, it needed another decade of prep work in order to have half as much success as it did.

The Jihad was always going to be the next major event, but the death of FASA and the failed reboot into Clicky-Tech messed up the timeline something fierce. Everything since that point has been the remaining/next generation devs trying to back-fit the decades prior to the Dark Age timeskip, and then move on from there. Honestly, I feel like they did what they could with what they had, but the whole thing was a mess from the beginning, and PorchBux's Liao bias didn't help.

Now, if the WoB had spent the '70s building up forces, co-opting local governments in the former Hegemony worlds, and working in secret to sabotage everybody, and then started the Jihad in the '80s, that would have made a lot more sense.

AK type rifles have been used by both deeply authoritarian regimes and straight up bandits, so it would be a mistake to characterize it as definitively chaotic. It would better be placed in Neutral Evil or True Neutral.

>Luger P08
Better suited for Lawful Evil, and even then it was not used exclusively under Nazi Germany where the P38 was more common.

>True Neutral
>FAL
Not a terrible choice but there's better options for True Neutral.

posts.com:
My name is Francis Tolliver. I come from Liverpool
Two years ago the war was waiting for me after school
To Belgium and to Flanders, to Germany to here
I fought for King and country I love dear
It was Christmas in the trenches where the frost so bitter hung
The frozen field of France were still, no Christmas song was sung
Our families back in England were toasting us that day
Their brave and glorious lads so far away
I was lyin' with my mess-mates on the cold and rocky ground
When across the lines of battle came a most peculiar sound

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Says I now listen up me boys, each soldier strained to hear
As one young German voice sang out so clear
He's singing bloody well you know, my partner says to me
Soon one by one each German voice joined in in harmony
The cannons rested silent and the gas cloud rolled no more
As Christmas brought us respite from the war
As soon as they were finished and a reverent pause was spent
God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen struck up some lads from Kent
The next thing sang was Stille Nach tis Silent Night says I
And in two tongues one song filled up that sky

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's someone coming towards us now the front line sentry said
All sights were fixed on one lone figure trudging from their side
His truce flag like a Christmas Star shone on the plane so bright
As he bravely trudged unarmed into the night
Then one by one on either side, walked in to No Mans Land
With neither gun nor bayonet, we met there hand to hand
We shared some secret brandy and we wished each other well
And in a flare lit football game we gave them hell
We traded chocolates, cigarettes and photographs from home
These sons and father far away from families of their own
Ton Sanders played the squeeze box and they had a violin
This curious and unlikely band of men
Soon daylight stole upon us and France was France once more
With sad farewells we each began to settle back to war
But the question haunted every heart that lived that wonderous night
Whose family have I fixed within my sights
Twas Christmas in the trenches and the frost so bitter hung
The frozen fields of France were warmed, the songs of peace were sung
For the walls they'd kept between us to exact the work of war
Had been crumbled and were gone forever more
Oh my name is Francis Tolliver, from Liverpool I dwell
Each Christmas comes since World War I have learned its lesson well
For the one who calls the shots won't be among the dead and lame
And on each end of the rifle we're the same
